Congratulations to the staff and students at Eliot Elementary School for being recognized by the California PBIS Coalition as a "Community Cares" school!

The CPC believes it is important to reflect on and share the positive experiences districts, schools, and educators have delivered to students and communities during these challenging times of the Covid-19 pandemic.

To honor the positive impacts schools are playing in the lives of California’s students, families, and communities, the CPC would like to recognize all schools that are providing services and supports during these challenging times. The CPC has developed a one-year-only “California PBIS Community Cares” acknowledgement to honor schools and community partners in this important work.

Learn more: http://www.pbisca.org/departments/educationalservices/prevention/cpc/pbis/Pages/staterecognition1920.aspx

Congratulations Eliot Lions! We are proud of you!

Beginning Wednesday, September 2, the Gilroy Unified School District will serve FREE meals for all children in Gilroy, ages 0-18, at four school sites: Eliot Elementary, Glen View Elementary, Rod Kelley Elementary and South Valley Middle School, Monday through Friday, from 12-2 pm daily.

In addition, through Friday, September 4, Luigi Aprea and Las Animas will also continue to serve meals, but only to GUSD students, and normal payment will be accepted based on meal eligibility.

On Tuesday, September 8, food service will transition from Las Animas Elementary to Solorsano Middle School, where ALL Gilroy children, ages 0-18 can receive free meals.

There will be no meals served at any GUSD school sites on Monday, September 7, in observance of the Labor Day holiday.

Our Child Nutrition Department will provide an additional update for our families this Friday, September 4.

For more information and to apply for free or reduced meals, visit our website: https://www.gilroyunified.org/parentstudent-resources/child-nutrition

The City of Gilroy Government is accepting applications for the Youth Commission. The Gilroy Youth Commission is an 11 member board, ages 12-19, who serve as a youth advisory group to the City Council, making recommendations on issues affecting local youth. The commission has extensive involvement with the planning, organization and implementation of programs and events in the community. Youth Commissioners serve a two-year term.

Applications are due September 8 and can be submitted to the City hard copy or electronically via the City's website: http://www.cityofgilroy.org/310/Youth-Commission

Fasten your seatbelts: GUSD Distance Learning launches today! Our teachers and staff are excited to reconnect with their students- we have missed you!!

Here are a couple of tips for success:
1. Log-in to your WebEx calls early. Give yourself some time to access a meeting, and have your meeting code and password available as you are logging in.
2. Be ready for school! Your participation in distance learning is similar to being in your classroom Arrive to your class time dressed and ready for the day.
3. Fuel your minds! Eat breakfast early, prior to your class meeting.
4. Be ready to learn! Have notebook and writing utensil available to take notes, write down assignments or make reminders for the week.
5. Be patient! Distance learning is new for ALL of us and we are all working through hiccups that may arise.
6. Ask questions. Communicate with your teacher frequently. about your experience with distance learning.

We will see you online! Here we go!

For more information, visit: https://www.gilroyunified.org/novel-coronavirus-information/gusd-distance-learning
